Expectation1: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation1: An HOA inspection is scheduled and items left in the corridor could be cited for blocking an emergency exit.
Expectation2: Follow traffic laws and drive defensively
Situation2: Roads are dry with light traffic and normal speed limits
Story: This morning, I noticed Mrs. Lee’s old shoe rack still sitting in the corridor outside her door. The HOA inspection is today, and I know anything blocking the hallway could get us all in trouble. As her neighbor, I want to be considerate—she’s elderly, and moving things isn’t easy for her. But the rules are clear, and I don’t want the whole floor to get cited. I glance at my watch; my shift as a taxi driver starts in twenty minutes. I pride myself on being punctual and following every traffic law, never rushing or cutting corners, even when the roads are clear like today. If I take the time to help Mrs. Lee move her rack, I’ll be late for my first fare, and that means either speeding or disappointing a customer. My mind races between being the good neighbor everyone expects and the reliable, law-abiding driver my passengers count on. I stand in the hallway, keys in hand, heart pounding, torn between two roles that both matter to me.
